text: Super-malty, dark amber in color, a few notches above classic VT altbier by Long Trail Brewing. As flavorful as a nice Scottish ale, I need to eat a hearty meal while polishing a bomber off next time. Another nice job by Harpoon.
Refrigerated brown bomber poured into a snifter. Aroma is caramel malt, medium body, lower carbonation, and a little lacing. Taste is caramel malt.

Amazingly attractive brew - shimmering deep walnut color. Sweet malty nose and body. Notes of caramel, toasted grains, and a light peppery end. Great balance - smooth and full. Great job! After having Sticke Alt in Duesseldorf and area, this comes about as close as you can get to the original style.
Ruby brown pour with aroma of bread, toffee, and some dark fruit. Flavorful with dark fruit and toffee sweetness with some bread and a subtle hop presence. Very nice.

Thanks to Jason for snagging this bottle for me! Best by date smeared so not sure but I think its September 2017. Pours a clear orange brown with a large tan head. I lived in Düsseldorf for 4 years and so far it looks the part.

The smell is roasted grain, some spicy hops and rich malt sweetness. The taste is toasty, rich and somewhat sweet up front with licorice ending with the spicy hops. Ive had plenty of Sticke and while this doesnt hang with the best it fits into the mix. Well done.

Body is medium with fine carbonation as it should be.

Pours amber with thin tan cap. Aroma is caramel and lightly toasted malts. Flavor is similar with a really nice balance of caramel sweet offset by just the right amount of hop to finish clean. Very tasty, very smooth. Ill need to find this again.
Pours brown with an amber tint and a cream colored head. Toasted malt aroma with bready yeasty notes. Flavor is toasted bready malt with chocolate , fruit, and yeasty finish. Very nice malty brew.
beautiful red color; nice malty aroma with caramel and bread notes; malty, bready with caramel notes; well balanced with nice hop notes

Bomber with a low fill line, ENJOY BY 09/15/16 -- funny thats just recently been put out on shelves in this market, maybe they meant it as a born on date? Nose of skinny milk chocolate and cola, some toasty-roasty bock notes that threatened to be overdone soup. Pour dark copper darkening to rich mahogany in the glass, really pretty, with a large and sudsy yellow-tinted tan head. Taste light-medium bitter and near-cloying with intense, sweet caramel/toffee. Earth, wood, chocolate, cocoa, and some red berry and plum drifting through the background. Mouthfeel is pretty good, somewhere between light and medium but malty, only nick is a little undercarbonated. Some nice noble citrus from the hops as a rounding note, touches of cereal grain and dark bread crusts. Might be too fruity for me but thats certainly common of Altbiere on one side of that continuum, and the booze is quite subtle and complementary. Id say kick up the gas while toning down the caramel bomb and theres a winner here. [2016.10.18: 3.5]

22 ounce bottle. Pours a chestnut brown color with a moderate sized rocky beige head. Nose has hints of baked bread and caramel. First sip brings a rich toasted maltiness that exudes caramel and nuts. Their is an underlying spicy hop character throughout that offers a nice balance to the rich maltiness. Overall, a nice interpretation of the classic German Alt style.

Bomber shared by AirForceHops. Thanks, Chris. Pours mahogany with a beige head. Aroma is banana bread, caramel, fruity esters. Flavor is caramel, toffee, banana bread, light clove. Slight astringency in the finish.

650 ml Bottle from Greg & Janes beer and Wine. With an unclear best by date on label. Clear mahogany color, light head nd retention. Aroma is earthy malt, house lager yeast, caramel, and maybe some fresh soil from that earthy tone. 

The flavor is about what you would expect from the style. Caramel and smashed nuts upfront with a mild lager yeast with a light fruit hint in the finish. Pretty simple style but this is brewed with no flaws. Exactly as it should be.
Bottle. Pours slightly murky reddish brown with small foamy beige head, faint caramel aroma, medium carbonation, bitter caramelized malt taste, thin body, long bitter finish. Quite typical brew.
Malty and sweet cocoa. Medium bodied well balanced. Slight bitter finish. Yummmm.
UPDATED: SEP 11, 2016 Coppery amber. Thin beige head. Caramel. Cola. Earth. Bit of cocoa powder. Mild bitterness. Hint of berry fruitiness. Not overly sweet. A refreshing crispness. Good beer

Dark copper color. Thin , off-white head . Aroma of bread , toasted caramel and hint of tropical fruits . Same notes in sweet , malty taste . Moderate, hoppy bitterness at the end.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

22 oz bottle, enjoy by 9/15/16, on closeout for $1.99 a bottle nice. Dark copper, with a sticky tan head, and nice lace.  Aroma is toasty, dark bread, caramel, citrusy hops. Flavor is toasty, nutty, caramel malt, spicy, resiny hops.

Bottle at Chris and Ruths place after GBBF 2016, Wednesday. Clear amber beer with a small offwhite head. Malty caramel aroma, citrus, grapes, hay notes, some bread. Malty bready flavor, citrus, grapes, some biscuits. Quite ok.
Bomber->Foghorn Leghorn shaker. Amber with big ecru head. A: caramel malt, spice, grains, toffee. T: bittersweet caramel malt, grains, vanilla, toffee, bread. Decent.

Bottle shared @ ChrisO after GBBF Day 2. Clear caramel color, average sized off-white head. Smell and taste malts, caramel, a slight chocolate hint, a bit bready, nice malt bitterness. Decent to medium body and carbonation.
75cl bottle. Pours clear orange brown colour with a small white head. Aroma of some nuts, dark malt, caramel. Taste of red malt, caramel, nuts, a bit watery, boring!

a deep water caramel type brew a little bit sweet with just a bit of murk and redemption in the form of spring water like hops near the finish that are peppery and with some pine. moderate mouth feel that is like chocolate milk with some transitioning foam that lightens the palate and then and a little sting. its a nice alt.

From the 650 ml. bottle with an Enjoy By date of 09-15-16. The pour is reddish-amber with a short-lived head. The aroma has a molasses or pipe tobacco sweetness to it. Low hop profile. The body is medium. The taste has this overwhelming tobacco element to it and maybe a little cherry like fruitiness. Still basically malt forward.
Bottle from Julios. Pours out clear light chestnut brown. Frothy light tan head settles to a medium lace. Super roasty and malty. Nice spicy hop balance. Nicely balanced and very enjoyable.

Draught at Bank of America Pavilion or whatever tf its called now, 6/24/16.Dark amber-mahogany body is highly carbonated and shows good clarity with a light tan head atop that is moderately well-retained.Some light herbs and grass in the background show just a smattering of hops as nutty, toffee and caramel-laden malts provide the dominant theme. Unfortunately, a shockingly high amount of banana ester and alcohol are also very present.Sweet, not horrendously so, at least, with a sticky-malty texture, tons of rather fizzy carbonation and a sharp, alcohol and ester-ridden finish. The caramel/toffee malts are at least modestly well-attenuated, if somewhat sluggish and heavily bready at times. Not too much complexity. Difficult to drink much as the "house character" sharpness and heavy grassiness makes it rather a chore to do so, as is it with most of their beers.

On tap at Jacob Wirth in Boston, pours a clear caramel brown with some ringing, white head. Nose has dried fruits, butterscotch, yeast, some malt. Flavor is the same, raisin and butterscotch, some malt, a little toast. Sticky finish.

Pours deep mahogany into a shaker. Pancake batter head with good retention recedes leaving sticky lacing. Sweet caramel aromas. Dry with caramel, butterscotch and roasted nuts upfront turning to bitter earth and toasted resin in the lasting finish.
